author: Morgan Housel
summary: Pessimism sounds smarter than optimism. Tell someone everything will be great and they shrug; tell them they're in danger and you have their undivided attention. But progress happens slowly while setbacks happen fast.
key_takeaways: Pessimism sounds smarter and more plausible than optimism.
Progress happens too slowly to notice; setbacks happen too quickly to ignore.
Pessimists extrapolate without accounting for how markets adapt.

questions.question: Why does pessimism get more attention than optimism in financial media?

options.text: Because threats are more urgent than opportunities from an evolutionary standpoint
Because optimistic news is illegal to broadcast

questions.explanation: Kahneman explains that organisms that treat threats as more urgent than opportunities have a better chance to survive and reproduce. We're wired to pay more attention to danger than opportunity.

questions.question: What is a common mistake pessimists make when forecasting economic problems?

options.text: They use too much historical data
They extrapolate present trends without accounting for how markets adapt
They are too focused on technology

questions.explanation: Pessimists often assume that something ugly will stay ugly. But problems correct and people adapt. Threats incentivize solutions in equal magnitude - that's a common plot of economic history.

questions.question: Why did it take years for people to recognize the significance of the Wright Brothers' airplane?

options.text: The Wright Brothers kept it secret
Progress happens too slowly to capture attention, while failures are immediate and obvious
Newspapers refused to cover technology news
The government suppressed information about it

questions.explanation: People were so convinced flying was impossible that they decided what they saw must be a trick. Growth is driven by compounding, which takes time. Destruction happens in seconds. Slow progress is harder to notice than quick failures.
